channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: In ‘Powerless,’ India’s Electricity Crisis Pits Maverick Against the State
item.description: From Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh, a look at how one man provides illegal power to those without electricity, and the government’s attempt to stop him.
item.dc:creator: By AARTI VIRANI
item.media:description: Loha Singh, one of the protagonists of the film "Powerless," is known to provide illegal electricity connections to locals in Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Satirizing China With the ‘China Daily Show’
item.description: There’s the state-run China Daily, there’s the satirical The Daily Show, and then there’s the China Daily Show, an online, “fake news” site in a country that is ripe for satire, says its creator.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screengrab from the home page of the China Daily Show.

item.title: Bangladeshi Collapse Kills Many Garment Workers
item.description: The police in Bangladesh said at least 175 people had died and many more were trapped after a building containing factories fell in an industrial suburb.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Inspectors found cracks in the building’s structure the day before it collapsed, local news reports said.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The Trans-Atlantic College Search
item.description: What happens when an American family lives overseas and it’s time to shop for college? A writer on higher education and his daughter begin their search. Has your family navigated this process?
item.dc:creator: By D. D. GUTTENPLAN

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 25
item.description: Hunger strike by Guantánamo prisoners; a premier is nominated in Italy; dying trees in Japan; ballet spreads in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: A video still from Guantánamo Bay shows an inmate meeting last week with medical personnel.

item.title: A Hired Killer in Syria Reconsiders His Role
item.description: With the aid of a group organized by an opposition figure, a young pro-Assad militia member renounces violence.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MIKE ELKIN and MIKEL AYESTARAN
item.media:description: Residents in the Tadamon neighborhood of Damascus inspected damage after a car bombing.

item.title: In Thailand, a Not-So-Glamorous Life on Stage
item.description: Itinerant Chinese opera singers are the gypsies of Bangkok, hauling their stages, their costumes, their musical instruments and their cooking gear from one Chinese temple to the next.
item.dc:creator: By SETH MYDANS
item.media:description: The young performers take a break.

item.title: South Korea Warns North of ‘Grave Measure’ in Factory Dispute
item.description: Concerns grow that South Korea could withdraw from a jointly operated industrial complex located in North Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Ultimatum on Talks
item.description: South Korea gave North Korea until Friday to respond to its proposal for dialogue on a joint industrial park or face a “grave measure” on the future of the factory complex.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: India Ink: Film Singer Shamshad Begum Dies at 94
item.description: The woman behind the voice that enthralled a generation of Bollywood aficionados died on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR
item.media:description: Shamshad Begum, right, being presented with the Padma Bhushan, India's third highest civilian honor, by then president Pratibha Patel in New Delhi on March 31, 2009.

item.title: Syria Campaigns to Persuade U.S. to Change Sides
item.description: As Islamists increasingly fill the ranks of Syrian rebels, President Bashar al-Assad is waging an energized campaign to persuade the United States that it is on the wrong side of the civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most of the prisoners, like Khaled Hamdo Shami, were Syrians, not from other countries.

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,182 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Boston Bombing Stirs Echoes of Unrest in Caucasus
item.description: How the situation in the Russian republic of Dagestan, where religious strife and anti-Russian feelings fuel relentless violence, may have played a role in a terrorist attack in Boston.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Guantánamo Prison Revolt Driven by Inmates’ Despair
item.description: With any decision about closing down the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, put on the back burner, inmates there have lost hope that they will ever be released.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: A video still from Guantánamo Bay shows an inmate meeting last week with medical personnel.

item.title: New Bird Flu Strain Spreads Outside of China
item.description: A man in Taiwan has contracted the H7N9 virus, and officials in the region are taking precautions to prevent spread to their countries.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG and DENISE GRADY
item.media:description: People wore masks in Shanghai on Tuesday in response to an outbreak of the H7N9 bird flu virus.

item.title: U.S. Unsure of Chemical Arms Use by Syria
item.description: The United States is waiting for the results of an exhaustive analysis of soil, hair and other materials to determine whether chemical warfare agents have been used.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, in Cairo on Wednesday, said the United States would not be rushed into action on Syria.

item.title: Boom Times in Paraguay Leave Many Behind
item.description: On paper, Paraguay is the fastest-growing country in the Americas, but its economic success exists only in pockets: more than 30 percent of the population lives in poverty.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fisherman on the polluted waters of a small river within sight of the towers of Asunción, Paraguay. The economy grows side by side with persistent poverty.

item.title: South Korea and U.S. Fail to Reach Nuclear Energy Deal
item.description: South Korea wants to be able to enrich uranium, but the United States worries that this could endanger efforts to curb North Korea’s nuclear ambitions.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Italian President Nominates New Prime Minister
item.description: The nominee, Enrico Letta, deputy head of the Democratic Party, said he would consult with the country’s leaders about its “fragile and unprecedented” political situation.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: Enrico Letta, the deputy head of Italy's Democratic Party, was appointed prime minister by President Giorgio Napolitano on Wednesday and tasked with forming a new government.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Quotas on Europeans
item.description: Swiss officials said Wednesday that they planned to restrict immigration from Western European countries starting next month, citing the high number of people coming to their country.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Treaty With Jordan Signed to Ease Deportation of Cleric
item.description: Britain has signed a new legal treaty with Jordan in the hope of deporting a radical cleric accused of being Osama bin Laden’s “right-hand man in Europe,” the interior minister said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Mauritania: Shortages Hit Millions
item.description: Twenty million people in the north African Sahel region are experiencing “serious” food shortages, aid workers said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Scores Dead in Bangladesh Building Collapse
item.description: An unknown number of people remained trapped after a structure that housed garment factories crashed down near Dhaka.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Ballet Gains a Toehold in the Middle East
item.description: The world's leading companies are adding the Gulf region to their itineraries, performing the classics to sold-out houses.
item.dc:creator: By SARA HAMDAN
item.media:description: The Mariinsky Ballet performed "Scheherazade" at this year's Abu Dhabi Festival.

item.title: Europe Faces Challenges in Effort to Embrace Shale Gas
item.description: Unsuccessful attempts at extraction, along with wary citizens and officials, have stymied the use of shale gas on the Continent.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Protesters in Bucharest, Romania, with one woman holding a sign that says, “Stop shale gas exploitation.”
